posts.name:
Himanshu Arya
Himanshu Arya
posts.content:
Ather Energy Takes a Big Step with Its IPO!

Ather Energy prepares to go public! With SEBI’s approval, Ather is set to launch its IPO, aiming to raise ₹3,100 crore through fresh shares and an offer-for-sale of 2.2 crore shares.

The company is targeting a valuation of $2.5 billion, showing its strong belief in shaping the future of electric mobility.

The funds from the IPO will be used to build a new factory in Maharashtra, invest in R&D, and expand marketing efforts. This step is not just about raising money—it’s about driving innovation and making EVs more accessible for everyone.

Backed by investors like Tiger Global, NIIF, and Binny Bansal, Ather has shown great determination despite challenges, including a net loss of ₹1,059.7 crore in FY24.

Their focus on pushing boundaries and creating a sustainable future makes this IPO a milestone for the EV industry.

comments.commentText: Inestors must think twice before investing in a standalone two wheeler company
Congratulations

posts.name:
Amanda Wright
Amanda Wright
posts.content:
Paid ads don’t fail because ads are bad. They fail because your product isn’t worth buying.

Marketers love blaming the algorithm, the targeting, the creative. Meanwhile, the product is overpriced, underwhelming, or both.

Fix the offer, then talk about your ad strategy.

comments.commentText: Here we go again!  creative has to be super on point though, and the landing page conversion rate has to be stellar. But you certainly need a good or unique product with a good profit margin or you can’t really market it effectively.

posts.name:

Jeff Roberts
posts.content:
Is Tesla's Optimus robot the next big step in robotics? 

A recent Barron's article explores its potential, from warehouse tasks to household chores. The goal? Making robots accessible beyond industrial use, opening doors to new possibilities in daily life.

This vision is exciting, but it raises big questions. Are we ready for robots in our homes? What ethical and societal challenges come with this shift?

Where do you see robots like Optimus making the biggest impact?

Read more on Barron's:

comments.commentText: Big shift! Are we ready? Probably not Jeff Roberts

posts.name:
Divya Jain
Divya Jain
posts.content:
When a country offers Rs.88 (€1) homes to combat population decline, it makes you think…

Italy is selling homes for just Rs.88 (€1) to fight empty towns. Meanwhile, India has a different story with 1.4 billion people. But here's what makes this interesting:

 Our people are our power
India will have the world's largest workforce by 2030 - over 1 billion strong
With an average age of 28 (compared to Italy's 47), we're young and ready to innovate

Our growing cities will drive 75% of India's future growth
Now, Italy’s 1 Euro homes reflect what happens when a population declines:
Economic stagnation sets in as the working-age population shrinks.

Local cultures and traditions fade without people to sustain them.
Infrastructure investments go to waste as schools, hospitals, and businesses shut down.

In India, our challenge isn’t depopulation but empowering our population:

1. Skills Gap: Only 20% of our workforce has formal training. Fixing this could add $700 billion to our economy
2. Women at work: Getting more women into jobs could boost our economy by 27%
3. Digital growth: With 850 million internet users, we can create jobs everywhere
4. The big picture: While some countries struggle to keep their towns alive, India's challenge is to empower its people and turn our numbers into our strength.

So, would you pick up an Italian home for Rs.88?

comments.commentText: Italy is selling homes for just Rs.88 (€1) to tackle population decline, highlighting the challenges of an aging society—economic stagnation, fading cultures, and wasted infrastructure. In contrast, India, with 1.4 billion people and an average age of 28, is poised to have the world’s largest workforce by 2030. The challenge for India isn’t depopulation but empowerment: closing the skills gap, increasing women’s workforce participation, and leveraging its 850 million internet users could unlock massive economic growth. While Italy works to fill empty towns, India’s focus is on turning its young, dynamic population into a global powerhouse.

Amit Mishra Absolutely, you’ve highlighted an interesting contrast! While Italy focuses on repopulating towns, India’s challenge is to empower its youthful population. Bridging the skills gap, increasing women’s workforce participation, and leveraging digital growth are indeed key to unlocking our full potential.
India’s youthful workforce and potential for innovation present an exciting opportunity to drive growth, unlike the challenges faced by declining populations, Divya Jain
Smriti Patel Absolutely! India’s young workforce is a huge advantage. While others face decline, we have the potential to drive innovation and growth.

posts.name:
Ivan Carillo
Ivan Carillo
posts.content:
Repeat after me: 

High precision matters (not only in the medical industry) 

The Cost of Poor Quality (COPQ) is a comprehensive concept
that measures the total costs associated with

+producing defective products
+delivering substandard services

Here's a detailed breakdown:

MAJOR CATEGORIES

1/ Prevention Costs
↳ Quality planning and training
↳ Process control and improvement
↳ Preventive maintenance

2/ Appraisal Costs
↳ Inspection and testing
↳ Quality audits
↳ In-process testing

3/ Internal Failure Costs
↳ Scrap and rework
↳ Downtime due to defects
↳ Troubleshooting/failure analysis

4/ External Failure Costs
↳ Customer complaints and returns
↳ Loss of customer goodwill
↳ Warranty claims

FINANCIAL IMPACT

 COPQ typically ranges from 15-40% of business costs
 It can reach up to 70% of total sales
 Higher COPQ in manufacturing than service industries

Best Practices to reduce COPQ:

1/ Implement robust quality management systems
2/ Focus on prevention rather than detection
3/ Use Six Sigma or other quality improvement methodologies
4/ Invest in employee training
5/ Establish supplier quality programs
6/ Regular monitoring and measurement of quality metrics
7/ Root cause analysis of defects

Your ultimate goal is to minimize COPQ through CI and proactive quality management

**
Follow mefor more

comments.commentText:
Precision isn’t just a buzzword - it’s a survival skill.

Ivan Carillo, this breakdown powerfully reminds me how the Cost of Poor Quality impacts every industry. My QC/QA lab experience shows how overlooking preventive measures can snowball into costly errors.

Start by tracking your internal failure costs. Identify one repeat issue, analyze its root cause, and implement a small, measurable solution. The ROI might surprise you.
Exactly, Philipp! Continuous improvement is crucial, and your approach to small, measurable changes is a wise strategy.
Philipp Osterwalder Totally misleading and baseless breakdown !
The shift from detection to prevention is key. Organizations that embrace this mindset truly excel in their industries.
KAIZEN Made Easy Agreed! When organizations focus on prevention, they not only excel but also sustain that excellence.

posts.name:
Ian Koniak
Ian Koniak
posts.content:
Hard closing never works when selling to Enterprise accounts.

There's one simple reason:

Your "champion" will hardly ever be the actual signer.

Often times, it will need to go to a CEO, CFO, or committee based on the dollar amount.

There are approvals and justifications needed at each level.

There will likely be legal, security review, and purchasing to deal with even after your champion says yes.

If you try to hard close, your commission breath may stain your relationship with your champion and you could risk losing the entire deal.

As an Enterprise Seller, your job is to help the client buy, rather than to hard close them.

You must understand their purchase process, timeline, and necessary steps so that you can partner together to bring this over the finish line.

Your job is to EMPOWER your champion with the right resources and assets to help them sell internally and justify the decision.

These assets include a Business Case, Future State Architecture, Implementation Plan, and Executive Summary.

If you've taken all the right steps in the sales process, "closing" should be the easiest part of the sale.

P.S.

if you'd like to learn the best way to close without applying icky pressure, you might be a fit for my coaching program. Book a free sales coaching strategy call here:

comments.commentText: solid approach! It’s all about building trust and understanding the long process
